sentence.text: ﻿The index patient (II.5), a 28-year-old woman, presented to our department because of short stature and joint deformity.
She wanted to benefit from the financial and social rights provided for disabled individuals.
The patient had pain in the hip joint and knee, which had increased over time, so it was not possible to work long hours, and it was very difficult for her to find a job.
The patient's family reported that the proband was born after an uneventful pregnancy at term with normal birth weight and height.
Short stature was detected around the age of two years.
Her parents were married first-degree cousins, the heights of the mother and father were 145 cm (−3.08 SD) and 165 cm (−1.81 SD), respectively.
In the physical examination of the patient, whose psychomotor development was normal, her height was 110 cm (−8.9 SD), and her head circumference was 53 cm (−2.2 SD).
The patient had a disproportionally short limbs, short and broad fingers, and also a single flexion line of the bilateral fifth finger/toe on the hands and feet.
Mild dysmorphic features were noted including mild brachycephaly, prominent and broad nasal bridge, prognathism, and short neck.
A radiologic examination of the spinal column showed an osteoporotic appearance, endplate irregularities of the vertebra, lumbar hyperlordosis, and irregularity and cupping in the costal ends.
In her upper extremities, there was bilateral radial angulation, a typical configuration of the metacarpal bones, and short middle phalanges in the fifth digits of the hands.
Irregularity of the iliac wings with a very short femoral neck was seen in her pelvic radiologic investigation.
Similar to the hand findings, there were fused middle and proximal phalanges in the fifth toes.
